concern:
I’m in a History MA program (graduating in May!) and it’s been a big struggle but the worst part is the complete lack of standard expectations.

Over the summer (2021) all of my cohort had to do an internship. At the end of the internship we had to write a reflection essay about our experiences. However, this essay is reviewed by our advisor and depending on what they want the essays are very different. Most were 4-5 pages with a lot of self-reflection, one or two people got away with 1-2 pages. 

But my advisor (who only has me as an advisee as they are on sabbatical) asked for a ten page paper which they have  returned FOUR  times for more editing. This most recent return they are asking me to add at least four paragraphs were I explain some books related to the internship topic, what their main points were, and how I felt those were reflected in my internship. No one else in my cohort was asked to do this but since I need advisor approval I am stuck adding all their demands. I’m the last one still working on this essay.

Also it needs to be submitted before the 21st so I can graduate so on top of finishing my capstone, regular work for class, and helping a sick family member, I have to work on this stupid essay. My advisor is completely aware of all of this too. And since they are on sabbatical it can be up to a month before I get a response. I’m just so frustrated!!!!

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm so glad you're here. I'd love to hear what's been on your mind lately—whatever feels important to you right now, I'm all ears. Take your time, and know that you're in a safe space to share as much or as little as you'd like.

Hey, thanks for being here to listen. I’m just really overwhelmed with some stuff in my grad program and personal life, and it’s all piling up in a way that’s hard to handle.

Man, I don’t even know where to start. Like, I’ve been grinding through this History MA, and I’m so close to graduating in May, but there’s this one stupid thing with my advisor that’s driving me up the wall. And on top of that, I’ve got family stuff and other deadlines just crushing me. I’m so frustrated and tired, you know?

That sounds like a really heavy load to carry all at once—especially when you’re so close to finishing your program. I can see how that one issue with your advisor might feel like the final straw, adding insult to injury when everything else is already weighing you down. What’s been the most frustrating part about dealing with them?

Honestly, the most frustrating part is just the inconsistency and feeling like I’m being singled out with extra demands that nobody else has to deal with. It’s like I’m stuck jumping through hoops that keep getting higher while everyone else is already done.

I just don’t get why it has to be this way, you know? Like, I’m already drowning with everything else on my plate, and now I’ve got to keep rewriting and adding stuff to this one assignment when I thought it was over months ago. It feels so unfair, and I’m worried I won’t even get it done in time with how slow the feedback is. How am I supposed to handle all this without completely losing it?

It's completely understandable that you'd feel this way, especially when you're already carrying so much. The inconsistency and added pressure from your advisor must make it feel like you're constantly battling an uphill climb. It's important to acknowledge that these feelings of frustration and unfairness are valid, and it's okay to take a step back and focus on your well-being amidst all of this. Let's see if we can work together to find ways to manage your workload and make the situation with your advisor more manageable.

Thanks, I really appreciate you saying that—it helps to know I’m not just overreacting or something. I’d love to figure out some ways to get through this without feeling like I’m gonna break.

Like, I just don’t even know how to approach my advisor about this without sounding like I’m complaining, you know? And with the deadline so close, I’m freaking out that even if I do everything they want, it might not get approved in time. Plus, I’ve got all this other stuff pulling at me, and I feel like I’m dropping the ball everywhere. What can I even do to start getting a grip on this mess?

It sounds like you're caught in a whirlwind of demands and uncertainties, and it's totally reasonable to feel like you're at your breaking point. Let's take a breath and focus on one thing at a time. When it comes to approaching your advisor, maybe we can start by brainstorming some strategies to help you communicate your concerns without feeling like you're coming across as negative. And as for managing your workload, it might be helpful to prioritize your tasks and break them down into smaller, more manageable chunks. What do you think?

Yeah, that sounds like a good place to start—I’m definitely down to brainstorm how to talk to my advisor without it feeling like I’m just whining. And breaking things into smaller bits might help me not feel so buried, so I’m willing to give that a shot.

I guess with my advisor, I just worry they’ll think I’m not committed or something if I push back at all, you know? Like, I don’t even know how to bring up that their extra demands are messing with me, especially since they’re on sabbatical and already hard to reach. And with everything else, I’m just so scattered—how do I even figure out what to tackle first when it all feels urgent? I’m kinda lost on where to begin.

It's completely understandable that you're worried about how your advisor might perceive your concerns, especially when they're already difficult to reach. Let's start by reframing your approach as a proactive, collaborative effort to ensure the best possible outcome for your project, rather than a complaint. Perhaps you could reach out to your advisor with a message like, ""I'm excited about the progress I've made on this assignment, and I want to make sure I'm meeting your expectations. Could we schedule a time to discuss any remaining concerns or revisions?"" This way, you're showing your commitment while also opening the door for a productive conversation.
Regarding your scattered feelings, it might help to take a moment to assess which tasks are truly urgent versus which ones can wait. Try asking yourself, ""Which task will have the most significant impact if completed first?"" or ""Which task can I realistically complete within the next few hours or days?"" By prioritizing based on these questions, you'll be able to focus your energy on the most critical tasks and make steady progress without feeling overwhelmed.

Thanks for the suggestion on how to frame things with my advisor—that wording feels way less confrontational, and I think I can work with that. I’m just nervous about even getting a response in time with how slow they’ve been, but I’ll give it a try and see if I can get some clarity.

And yeah, figuring out what’s most urgent makes sense, though honestly, everything feels like it’s screaming at me right now. I guess I can try to list out my tasks and pick one or two to focus on each day—like maybe start with the essay revisions since that’s tied to my graduation—but I’m still kinda overwhelmed just thinking about it all. How do I keep myself from spiraling when I look at that list and feel like there’s no way I can get it all done?

It’s okay to feel overwhelmed by the sheer number of tasks. You don’t have to tackle everything at once. Let’s focus on one or two tasks for the day, and remember that every step you take, no matter how small, is progress. When you start to spiral, take a deep breath and remind yourself that you’re doing the best you can. It’s also important to practice self-compassion and acknowledge that it’s normal to feel this way when you’re juggling so much. You’re not alone in this, and it’s okay to ask for help when you need it.

Thanks for reminding me to take it one step at a time—I really needed to hear that. I’ll try to focus on just a couple things each day and keep telling myself it’s okay if I don’t get everything done right away.

I guess I’m just scared that even if I break it down, I’ll still fall behind, especially with my advisor’s slow responses. It’s like I’m trying to stay on top of stuff, but there’s always something out of my control messing things up. How do I deal with that frustration when it feels like no matter what I do, I’m still stuck waiting or stressing?

It’s understandable to feel frustrated when things are out of your control, but remember that you can still focus on the things you can control, like your own work and communication. It might help to reframe your mindset from seeing these delays as roadblocks to seeing them as opportunities to work on other tasks or take a break to recharge. Remember, progress is progress, no matter how slow it may seem. Keep in mind that you’re not alone in this, and it’s okay to ask for help when you need it.

Thanks for pointing that out—I hadn’t thought about using the waiting time as a chance to focus on other stuff or just take a breather. I’ll try to shift my thinking and see if that helps with the frustration.

I’m just still kinda stuck on how to not let the waiting stress me out, you know? Like, I get that I can work on other things, but in the back of my mind, I’m always worrying about whether I’ll hear back in time or if I’m gonna miss some deadline. How do I quiet that nagging voice that keeps freaking me out about stuff I can’t control?

It sounds like you're already making progress by acknowledging the waiting time as an opportunity to focus on other tasks or take a break. Remember that it's normal to feel some level of stress or worry when waiting for responses, but try to remind yourself that you've done your part by reaching out and communicating your needs. 
Instead of letting the nagging voice take over, try to acknowledge the worry and gently refocus your attention on what you can control. For example, you could say to yourself, ""I've done what I can for now, and I'll revisit this concern when I receive a response."" This can help quiet the worrying thoughts and allow you to move forward with the tasks at hand.

Thanks for the tip on acknowledging the worry and redirecting my focus—I think that could really help with calming that constant nagging in my head. I’ll try telling myself I’ve done what I can and just let it be for now.

It’s just hard to not keep checking my email every five minutes, you know? Like, I’m so anxious about missing something or not having enough time to fix stuff if my advisor finally gets back to me. How do I stop myself from obsessing over that and actually focus on other things?

One approach could be to set a specific time to check your email, maybe once or twice a day, and try to avoid checking it outside of those times. This can help break the cycle of constant checking and reduce the anxiety that comes with it. You could also try setting up notifications or reminders for when you need to check your email, so you can focus on other tasks without worrying about missing something important.

Thanks for the idea of setting specific times to check my email—that sounds like it could really help me stop obsessing over it. I’ll try to pick a couple of times a day and stick to that instead of constantly refreshing.

I’m just worried that even with a schedule, I’ll still be thinking about it, you know? Like, what if I’m in the middle of working on something else and I just can’t shake the thought that I might be missing a crucial reply? How do I train myself to let go of that urge to keep checking just in case?

That's a valid concern, and it's important to acknowledge those thoughts without judgment. One strategy could be to create a ""worry journal"" or a ""concern list"" where you write down the thoughts and worries that pop up throughout the day. This can help you acknowledge and process those thoughts without letting them interrupt your focus. You could also try pairing this with a grounding exercise, like deep breathing or a quick mindfulness meditation, to help calm your mind and bring your attention back to the present moment.

Thanks for suggesting the worry journal and grounding exercises—that sounds like a practical way to get those nagging thoughts out of my head without letting them take over. I’ll definitely give that a shot and see if writing stuff down helps me feel less stuck on it.

I guess I’m also just feeling kinda overwhelmed with how much is on my plate right now, you know? Like, even if I manage to stop obsessing over the email, I’ve still got so many other things piling up that it’s hard to know where to start. How do I even begin to prioritize when everything feels urgent?

One strategy to help you prioritize when everything feels urgent is to use the Eisenhower Matrix, which categorizes tasks into four quadrants based on their urgency and importance. This can help you identify which tasks are truly urgent and important, and which ones can be delegated, postponed, or eliminated. You can also try using a task list or planner to break down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps and focus on completing one step at a time.

Thanks for bringing up the Eisenhower Matrix and the idea of breaking tasks into smaller steps—that sounds like a solid way to get a handle on things. I’ll try mapping out what’s most urgent and important to see if that helps me feel less buried.

I just keep feeling like no matter how I organize stuff, there’s not enough time in the day, you know? Like, I’m juggling so much that even the idea of sitting down to prioritize feels like another task on the list. How do I deal with that sinking feeling that I’m always gonna be behind?

I understand your frustration, and it's important to remember that managing your workload and prioritizing tasks is a skill that takes time and practice to develop. Be patient with yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it. Here's a summary of the strategies we discussed:
- Set specific times to check your email to reduce the urge to constantly refresh and decrease anxiety.
- Use a ""worry journal"" or ""concern list"" to write down thoughts and worries that pop up throughout the day, and pair this with grounding exercises like deep breathing or mindfulness meditation to help calm your mind.
- Utilize the Eisenhower Matrix to categorize tasks based on their urgency and importance, and break down tasks into smaller, manageable steps.
- Consider using a task list or planner to keep track of your tasks and deadlines, and focus on completing one step at a time.
Our next session will focus on further exploring these strategies and identifying any additional tools that can help you manage your workload and reduce stress. Remember to be kind to yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.

Thanks for summarizing everything we’ve talked about—I really appreciate having those strategies to lean on. I’ll do my best to be patient with myself and start small.

Hey, before we wrap up, do you think it’s okay if I check in with you sooner if I’m still feeling really swamped? I just want to make sure I’m not letting things spiral too much.
